Over the last decades there have been remarkable developments in thermodynamics and quantum mechanics. Yet many of the basic problems have remained largely unsolved. In the spectrum of opinions expressed by authors who have attempted to solve these problems, one can roughly distinguish three main schools of thought:

1) Traditional axiomatic thermodynamics, which cannot explain the origin of irreversibility and time asymmetries.

2) The statistical school, which generates “man-made irreversibility’’ by imposing asymmetric conditions on symmetric ones in order to describe reality.

3) The new gravitational school, which deduces the origin of evolution, irreversibility, electromagnetic and thermodynamics from Einsteinian gravitation and the verified expansion of the universe.
This school includes some new modifications to physics, as part of GRAVITISM.

My object is to obtain a consistent mathematical formulation of irreversibility in probabilistic theories. So far physicists have done this by means of (a priori) imposing on symmetric equations an (often hidden postulate of) asymmetry (which, in itself, is equivalent to the very results that the mathematical analysis is aimed “to prove”). In other words, the (asymmetric) “results” (of classical and quantum-statistical physics) are not really results for they are deliberately enforced on, not deduced from symmetric formalism.

Such tactics are unacceptable, They lead to misleading philosophy of science, which, in turn, has generated a ludicrously incongruous mode of thinking in education and philosophy E.g. when, in 1915, Einstein discovered pre-existing Mercury mathematics-physics, it was not man-made, it was "there" at least since "genesis".

Advocates of man-made irreversibility fall into the trap of assuming that which they set out to prove, and it was already "There". Imposed, man-made mathematics, to fit extant reality, cannot get uncertainty for certainty, nor indeterminism from determinism (see below).* These conclusions lead to somewhat surprising results, which, in turn, are related to the very core of our physical theories and to the role of time, causality, and determinism in philosophy.

When we draw a sine wave on a blackboard, we are representing spatial curvature. Does a photon transfer spatial curvature from one location to another? (Quarks/Gluons) The "Color Force" would be related to the XYZ coordinates (orientation) of entanglement. "Asymptotic Freedom", and "flux tubes" make sense based on this concept. Not sure if just bad word choices or just plain wrong.  Aren’t you a professor?  First, “as your electrons are traveling through space time they interact with the Higgs field and it is that that gives them their mass, it slows them down and stops them from traveling at the speed of light.”   This is just wrong.  The Higgs field does not slow anything down, it is NOT like molasses.  If it were true that Higgs slowed particles down then all particles that interact with Higgs would very quickly come to a complete stop.  Second, the Higgs field IS what grants the mass to, in your example, an electron.  It is not energy bound in the subatomic particles.  What are you talking about?  The Higgs field allows atomic entities like the electron to borrow and give back energy which is used to flip its spin.  The borrowing and giving of energy does not in any way affect the actual Higgs field, this is its unique property.  The back and forth flipping of the electron as it propagates through space time is the property that we call mass by definition.

Throughout the decades, many scientists have been baffled by the experiment once conducted by an American physician, Dr.Mcdougall. The experiment consisted of weighing a person's weight once the person was proclaimed dead. Mcdougall's research concluded that in the precise moment of death, the patient lost about three-quarters of an ounce or about 21g of mass. Mcdougall took this as an indication that humans have souls and that the estimated weight of these souls was 21g. Many people have taken this as an indication that humans, in-fact have souls. However, today I stumbled across another video published by, Verytasium In which he states that "21G that is the mass of all the electrons in your body." He states that this is due to your electrons traveling through space-time and interact with the Higgs field and is the Higgs Field that gives them their mass, slows them down, and stops them from flying out at the speed of light. Then he moves on to a different subject that is unrelated to this. However, the moment I had hers this my brain clicked in a way that made me realize that I've heard that calculation of mass somewhere else. that's when I stumbled across the, studied done by Mcdougall, which in the past I've heard about his experiments but I never really knew who he was. The moment I realize these two things were related, the mass you lose when you die and the number of electrons in your body. My Hypothesis is that once you die the electrons inside your body stops interacting with the Higgs field there for are now free to leave the body therefore explaining the loss of weight at the moment of death. I believe this is what Mcdougall had confused for the human soul, but in reality, it could just be the electrons in our body leaving.

Einstein's 'Tea Cup' Analogy is flawed:  If he means filling the filling the cup to the same level with a hot liquid (A) or cold liquid (B), the cold liquid will ALWAYS have more mass relative to the hot liquid of same volume. Here's where my head's at currently. Mass creates irregularities in the spacetime coordinate system. We call these irregularities "gravity". (So far, I'm not making anything up. In Einstein's model, gravity is not a force. Instead, it's a coordinate system deformation. Einstein envisioned a four-dimensional system. Three of those dimensions are the 3D we're already familiar with. Those three dimensions are all at right angles to each other. The fourth dimension is time, pointing to the future and the past, which is also at a right angle to all of the other three. Don't try to picture what it looks like, because it's impossible to "visualize". Anyway, in Einstein's model, when gravity is observed, the "time" dimension is no longer at a 90 degree angle to the spacial dimensions. It actually "leans" into space. The Moon doesn't orbit Earth because there's a force pulling it to Earth. Rather, Earth's gravitational field, which is not a force, alters the Moon's "future" axis in such a way that its future is intrinsically bound to the spacial dimensions. And since we know that mass resists forces, and this deflection scales up with mass [a little too convenient], we classically attribute this deflection to a force that scales up with mass. Incorrectly.) This gravity has the potential to alter the trajectory of all sorts of things. And there must be some "cost" for influencing this, because it's very influential. Even light appears to curve because of gravity.

A gravity well moving constantly in a straight line (or a geodesic in relativity) doesn't cost anything because its straight-line trajectory is the same as not moving at all (see: relativity, tensor transformations). The only time the gravity well really changes for all observers is when it's accelerated. Or "shoved", if you will. The coordinate system resists being shoved, because that's fair. It literally influences everything.

So I don't think of it as moving mass. I think of it as moving gravity wells.

Now, as for why mass creates gravity wells, whoops looks I'm out of time. Just kidding; I have no idea.

It is a tautology to say your mass comes from your energy.  Recollect that E = mc**2, but c squared is just a constant so if we had chosen our units in which things get measured appropriately we would have E = m. Or to paraphrase in more normal English: Energy IS Mass and vice versa.  Another analogy: suppose you go to the bank and enquire about your bank balance. The teller informs you that you have a balance of $1. You then ask where did that $1 come from to which the teller replies "Oh, its because you have 100 cents" - it doesn't add any more information. Under Special relativity, when an object moves at a speed approaching light velocity, the object shrinks in the direction it moves. Thus distance between two charges in the object also shrinks, and the mass as charges squared divided by distance between two charges increases. However the distance between two charges will although approaches zero, never be actually zero. Therefore the mass of the object will be large but not infinitely large.

Mass(in kilograms)=Charges squared (in Coulombs squared) x 10 to the power minus 7 divided by distance (between two charges in meters). That's how Newton's Law of Universal Gravitation is equivalent to Coulomb's Law, and thus works for NASA.

I was researching about Higgs field and the origin of mass, I developed a research paper proposing that the mass of any particle is not its own property and hence it states that the particle is gaining its mass from external interactions. I want to know if should continue working on this research paper or my ideas and interpretations are not realistic?

Here are my views in a detail,

Abstract
The standard model of particles describes the different particles based on their properties, in which Higgs boson was not yet discovered. On 4 July 2012, the Large Hadron Collider found the remaining particle “the Higgs Boson.” Following the existence of Higgs boson, the proof for the existence of Higgs field was also found. The theory of Higgs field defines mass as the result of the interaction of fundamental particles with the Higgs field. The interaction resists the fundamental particles from traveling at the speed of light. The process of encountering resistance due to Higgs field is when an object gains mass. The mass due to Higgs field is not its own mass. All the particles of the universe are massless by themselves. The mass known currently is due to Higgs field as Higgs field is present universally.


Introduction
Today in the 21st century, we measure something in two forms “Mass and Weight.” Mass is the amount of matter in the substance. Whereas Weight is the effect of gravitation force on the mass of an object. We have studied that anything that has mass and occupies space is matter. According to our current understanding of particle physics, a proton is made up of 2 up quarks, and 1 down quark and these quarks are bound together by gluons. The mass when combined with 2 up quarks and 1 down quarks should be equal to the mass of the proton, as gluons are massless. But this combined mass is only 1 % of the total mass of the proton. The remaining 99% mass of the proton is due to the energy of the gluons known as quantum chromodynamics binding energy. Through the mass composition, we can conclude that the energy is equal to mass as mass is due to the energy of gluons. Because the mass is due to the quantum chromodynamics binding energy of gluons they should be considered the matter. Contrast to these mathematical calculations, the current theory of particle physics describes gluons as massless. Due to the inconsistency of data, I conclude that the definition of matter is wrong. Thus, proving the currently known mass of proton wrong according to E=Mc2 as the energy and mass are interchangeable in certain conditions but not equal. As the definition of mater was crafted when the Higgs field was not yet discovered, the definition becomes invalid after the L.H.C discovered the Higgs boson on 4 July 2012. Following the discovery of Higgs boson the Higgs field was proven to have existed, as Higgs boson is an excitation in the Higgs field. After the Higgs field was confirmed to exist, its properties hold true after that. The most important property of the Higgs field is that it gives mass to fundamental particles when interacting with the Higgs field. For example, proton’s mass was measured when the Higgs field was not yet then discovered, so the mass of proton measured was in the presence of Higgs field. This implies that the mass measured was due to the interaction with the Higgs field and not the own respective mass of the proton. This theory holds true for everything which has mass according to our current understanding of measurement of mass.
As all particles are made up of fundamental particles, so when the particle for example proton interacts with the Higgs field, the fundamental particles that make up the proton also interact as a proton is a name given to the composition of 2 up quarks and 1 down quark held together by gluons. The properties of Higgs field states that any fundamental particle when interacts with the Higgs field, it generates mass. Thus, concluding that the mass of a proton is due to Higgs field.

Since light is a disturbance in the electron field, and this disturbance propagates at a finite speed (the speed of light), how fast does the disturbance in the quark field propagate? Without assuming that quark field disturbances propagate at the speed of light, how can we determine the propagation speed through the mechanics of quarks and quark fields? To my knowledge, the quarks and quark fields (or gluons) are primarily (if not the only thing) responsible for the strong nuclear interactions, A.K.A. the strong nuclear force. But the strong force interaction is limited to a distance on the order of 1 femtometer (10^ -15 m). We obviously do not have the microscopic technology to probe disturbances in the quark field to that scale; so then, how can we, experimentally or through a process of deduction determine the propagation speed of what I would call "quark waves"?

Another way for me to ask the same question is this: The electric permittivity and magnetic permeability of free space determine the speed of light. But these properties of space are related to the electron field. Is there such thing as a "quark field permittivity" and "quark magnetic permeability" of free space which determine the propagation speed of quark waves? If so, then how could we determine if they equate to or are different from the electric permittivity and magnetic permeability for the electron field?

IF quark waves were experimentally determined to propagate faster than the speed of light, would the capabilities to manipulate (amplify and extend the interaction distance of) quark waves enable us, theoretically, to break the light barrier, not through the manipulation of electromagnetic forces but through the manipulation of quark field disturbances (or through the manipulation of the quark permittivity and quark permeability)?

Wonderful fantasy explanation of what accounts for the mass of things like electrons and protons. We learn that electrons only look like they have mass because of the drag they experience while moving through the Higgs field surrounding them. Sounds good until you realize that electrons still have mass when they are motionless! The Higgs field is completely imaginary as was the ether theory of the 19th century, imo. As for protons being "made up" of quarks is concerned, it never ceases to amaze me that particle physicists never consider the possibility that quarks have no independent existence in nature, but are only momentarily created when proton abuse takes place inside of a particle collider because the energy needed for such collisions does not occur in the real universe. I think one should be wary of any physical models fabricated from a zoo-like collection of ad hoc subatomic particles. Note that the collisions between the protons are always head to head in the particle colliders. Maybe changing the angle of the collisions or further increasing their energies (poor protons!) would then result in a completely different collection of "fundamental" particles being collected for the particle physicists' zoo. Then, we have a final embarrassing question to ask. Has anything practical ever come out of all of this expensive high energy particle research? Has it allowed us, for example, to artificially control the gravitational and inertial properties of matter? No. Has it allowed us to generate all of the energy we need with "cold fusion"? No. Has it allowed us to disintegrate waste to get rid of it? No. Other than providing some employment for physicists, I have not seen much come out of it in decades. Hopefully, we'll finally see something worth the investment in the future.

Like yeah, it's cool and truly amazing that we can observe these things and attempt to understand them, but at the same time at what point will we be satisfied and just shrug saying "that's just the way it is". I know that's not the scientific way of doing things, but at the same time how can one truly explain something that is so small and energetic it actually cannot be perceived?
It's like we are a cell in a huuuuuuuge body-- the universe-- and we are trying to explain what's inside of us, while simultaneously trying to explain what we are inside of. Not knowing the whole time, that what we are inside of is inside of something bigger, and what's inside of us is made up of trillions of other little things a fraction of their size. OMG, quantum physics just keeps getting kookier all the time. Being somewhat knowledgeable about the history of the development of Quantum theories I have noticed that while it does become more elaborate over time, giving smaller scale explanations for what is seen at larger scales, at any point in the history the explanation leaves unexplained whatever is at that time claimed to be the reason for all the claims at the next higher scale and on up. They drill down and down, building a framework of higher level explanations, but are mystified by whatever happens to be at the bottom of the hole at that time. However, history shows that there is a tendency to claim "aha" , this bottom of the hole is it. Of course they will also say more funds are needed to see if the hole can be dug deeper. And they get the funds and dig deeper, and after a little digging say "aha" again. This pattern keeps repeating. I see no conjectures or theories offered as to how it may one day be known that the true bottom of the hole has been reached. So I opine that the true bottom of the hole will become "true" only when a lot of time, maybe a century has passed since the last time someone said "aha".

Meanwhile, at any point in this history, parrots learn to repeat the words they last heard with religious assertiveness, seemingly unaware that the bottom of the hole has not been reached, and the next "aha" is going to change the storyline to some degree, making the parrots words obsolete. I don' t mean totally obsolete, I just mean that the parrot will have to learn some new phrases and forget some already learned.

I don't mean this as a put down to the quantum physicists.....of course what they do is amazing. But let me add a second observation. 50 or more years ago the common phrase was " scientists will one day unlock the secrets of the universe" and that was always said with a hopeful tone, as if after unlocking the last most diffucult to crack locks some fantastic knowledge would be gained that would usher in a utopia more utopian than ever imagined, bringing unlimted energy and abundance to all, and even the knowledge itself would blanket humanity with a kind of ultimate bliss. It is disappointing to me that what quantum theory says, more and more, is that things are such that only totally impractical and unreachable levels of energy are needed to change anything, for instance to change lead into gold or to make a new stable element with amazingly useful and beneficial properties. Of course some useful, beneficial knowledge has come from all this, but IMO rather little compared to all the fine details that have been explained. We have nuclear medicine...a useful but limited invention. We have nuclear power, but it has serious drawbacks and the uranium supply is limited. We have xray inspection of steel structures to detect flaws. And of course there is nano-tech, but that's all at the atom level....manipulation of atoms that has produced a little bit of useful tech and may produce more but what's that got to do with gluons? For the most part what we know now about "the secrets of the universe" is a bit of a downer, as it points as I mentioned to little good news ahead, due to energy level limitations. In other words it looks like it is what it is, what we hoped it was not, namely, more or less unchangeable and without much promise.

Much, much more promise seems to lie in the fields of bio-tech and computing. Faster, cheaper, more efficient computing will be a good thing but to what extent it will bring about utopian results I am uncertain....I think it may end up telling us it is what it is, but tell us with more energy efficiency and in less time.

Back to my original claim that quantum physics is sounding kookier all the time...this is partly because there are serious semantic impediments to explaining the oddness that is being observed....I don't just mean explaining to the layman, but we may not have the words or even the concepts to really make sense of it. Maybe there is more to it than we will ever know because we can't conceptualize it. Put another way, if there is no benefit to be had then there is no meaning and then talking about it will be babble.

Well... I think that there is a common misconception on the mass that is not explained in the video: THERE IS TWO KIND OF MASS.

In the video, you assume that they are both the same, but at the quantum level, this is not so obvious.

1- The gravitation mass: this is the "charge" that make your particle "feel" the gravitation field.

2- The inertial mass: this is the mass that is in relation with the "quantity of stuff". More you have stuff, more it is difficult to move it.

So, in the video, you talk about the second one even if it is not clear. But what you don't explain is: ok, so almost all the mass of the proton depends on quantum field fluctuations.

But you don't explain how thoses fluctuations can "weigh" something. How those fluctuactions stop the proton to move more freely like if he was made of only 3 quarks. In brief: How the quantum vacuum in the proton can have inertia whereas outside of the proton, we don't assign any mass to it (the quantum vaccum) even if it is still there... This video should be removed.  It is misleading and fails to explain what the Higgs field is and how it is believed to work.  This video refers to a "Higgs mechanism" but does not explain how this mechanism relates to the Higgs field.  Even more disturbing is that this video limits the effects of the "Higgs mechanism" to only electrons, when in fact that Higgs field acts on all subatomic particles, giving rise to mass in all particles that interact with the Higgs field.

Quarks also gain their mass from the Higgs field.  The fundamental concept behind Higgs boson is that the Higgs field creates mass by slowing down particles traveling at the speed of light.  This covers all particles including quarks.  Therefore, the Higgs is responsible for all of our mass and the mass of all objects around us.  It is what gives rise to mass.

The quark and anti-quark are literally created out of thin air. The law of conservation of mass is not a real law, it's only an approximation in normal day life physics. When you get down the microscopic scale, the real conservations are energy and momentum (and a few others).

While more mass = more energy, it DOES NOT mean higher temperature (if you ignore biological metabolism and all that). As an absolutely trival example, 2 liters of water has more mass than 1 liters of water, though they can comfortable have the same temperature on the stove.

What happens when two magnetic monopoles are in a superconductor?  Well, due to the "Meissner effect", the presense of magnetic field causes a lot of energy. To minimize that energy, the field lines have to occupy as little space as possible, and hence they are stretched like spaghetti to minimize the energy, forming a flux tube. If you want, there is a nice "less technical"
 article by Prof. Matthew Strassler titled "on confinement and duality", you can google and download it.

While I generally liked the video, some facts are wrong in the video. Flux tubes created by two quarks ARE NOT the lack of gluon fields. The QCD vacuum is analogous to a superconductor (except it is a superconductor for magnetic QCD field, instead of electric field in the case of electromagnetism). So one can analogously view the configuration of two quarks in the vacuum like the configuration of two magnetic monopoles in a superconductor

As a further example, suppose that we now have two particles. Now it is possible that there is no frame in which both are at rest. Here while each particle is individually at rest (or can be thought of as such) relative to the Higgs field, it is not possible to find a frame in which both are simultaneously at rest, and hence the fact that the Higgs interaction increases with speed matters.

Absolutely! This is a fascinating question. Consider the following scenarios:
1. A particle sits at rest and interacts with the Higgs field.
2. A particle moves to the right at 50% c and interacts with the Higgs field.
Special relativity requires that we be able to shift at will between these two frames. As far as the Higgs field is concerned they are precisely equivalent, and so we can see that if the mass goes up in scenario 2, the Higgs interaction must just be larger.

That is *a* definition, but not is the standard one. The definition which the Higgs mechanism refers to is gravitational/inertial mass.

The first definition is the inertial definition and the second is the gravitational definition (i.e., a gravitational "charge"). The concept of rest mass is from relativity and my understanding is that the idea of rest mass is not used anymore. Leonard Susskind describes mass as the energy inherent in a system regardless of its velocity.

That's not strictly true. The mass is defined in two distinct ways:
1. The amount of force required per unit acceleration required to accelerate the system.
2. The amount of gravitational force exerted per unit mass of the object feeling the gravitational force.

These definitions are, by the equivalence principle, the same. They make no reference to the mass at rest. What you are referring to has a special name in fact: it is called the rest mass of the system.

In and of itself it wouldn't. The point though is that all of the mass contained within the system is fundamentally from interaction with the Higgs field. That is, even if the *rest* mass of the gluons is tiny compared to their kinetic mass, their kinetic mass is a direct result of the Higgs field as well. It doesn't make sense from to treat kinetic and rest mass distinctly from this point of view.

It's more that the Higgs mechanism provides a description for mass which is consistent with what is observed in special relativity, and that includes the relativistic invariance of rest mass and the increase in inertial mass that comes from a non-rest frame.
Recall that *all* mass fundamentally comes from interaction with the Higgs field.

There aren't any readily-available everyday-world analogies to use. Everything is described in mathematical detail. The difference between up, strange, and charmed quarks lies in their mass, spin, charge, and other properties. Color is the name of the charge in reference to the strong force. It is a three-way charge and is similar to the red-green-blue of an additive color palette, as in a computer monitor.

In physics, the mass is defined by the amount of energy in a system at rest, so energy IS mass (E = m, when c = 1). The Higgs field produces mass through some low-energy symmetry breaking. When energies are high enough to leave symmetry unbroken, then all elementary particles are massless. 1. This is a somewhat subtle point. As a particle acquires kinetic energy its interaction with the higgs field increases: this is why, for example, a particle moving at 0.99c is harder to accelerate than a particle moving at 0.01c.
2. No. This is a mathematical convention which is used for forces that decay as r^(-n) for some positive constant n. The zero point of the potential is arbitrary. The convention for attractive forces which go as r^(n) (which is how color charge works) is V=0 at r=0.

You're right that they likely contribute little, but the point is that all of the mass at the end of the day is due to interaction of particles (and virtual particles) with the Higgs field. I'm not sure that the arithmetic works out... the potential ought to be defined to be zero at zero separation (meaning positive energy as you move out). At any rate all of this is just approximate: there is a whole renormalization scheme for talking accurately about masses.

While they are massless, higher order loops give an effective contribution from the Higgs mechanism (gluon->quark antiquark pair, which interacts with Higgs, then ->gluon).

In asymptotically confined theories it doesn't make a whole lot of sense to call the binding energy negative, as the statement "consider three quarks infinitely far apart" has very little meaning, in the same way that it doesn't make sense to use positive binding energies for gravitational theories.

Nope: The Higgs mechanism actually couples much more strongly to gluons and quarks than to electrons. You can view the mass of a particle as a measure by definition of how strongly the Higgs mechanism couples to them.

What makes something with more energy have more mass? Or as in, how does e = mc^2 relate energy, mass, and light together?

Any energy, any at all, whether it's kinetic energy or chromodynamic potential energy or electromagnetic potential energy, adds mass.

The atom gains a little mass from the electrons' binding energy, but it's not very significant.  The strong force and electromagnetism work differently; electromagnetic potential energy goes down asymptotically to zero as distance increases, whereas chromodynamic potential increases linearly to infinity.

Ice is lighter (less dense) than water because H2O is a polar molecule. This means that it has a dipole moment (one part of the molecule is more positive, the other is more negative). When water freezes, it must arrange itself so that the positive areas line up with the negative areas (opposites attract) between all of the molecules. This very organized structure takes up more space (more space = less dense) than if the molecules were just floating about freely as they are in liquid water.

typo: total 5.91k baryons

Human body composition by relative molarity is as follows: 
H - 63%
O - 24%
C - 12%
Other < 1%
let k be an arbitrary constant 
H has only a proton, so we have 0.63k protons. 
O has 8 of each, so in the body, it has 1.92k n, 1.92k p
C has 6 of each, so in the body, it has 0.72k n, 0.72k p
That's a total of 3.27k protons out of 5.91 baryons, which is 0.5533 of baryonic mass.
The <1% elements are heavier, and have more n than p, but they're negligible.

Mass of the atmosphere=4*Pi*(6.4E6 m)^2*(9.4E5 Pa)/(9.8 m/s^2) =~5E18kg
Atmosphere is ~70% Nitrogen and ~20% Oxygen, their average specific heat with N_2 weighted more heavily is ~1 kJ/kg*K.
To raise the global temperature by 4 degrees (for example), we have 4*1E3*5E18 = 2E22 J. To get the mass of this energy we divide by c^2 or (3E8)^2, leaving us with about 200,000 kilograms. So if you raise the global temperature by 4 degrees, you get about the mass of a freight train.

I'll use water molecules for example. Cooling ice from 30 degrees to absolute 0 is a 273 degree change, and changing a kilogram of ice a degree requires 2108 joules of energy, so 2108*273 = 575484 joules to cool barely frozen ice to absolute zero. By e=mc^2, the coefficient of change is ~90 quadrillion (c^2). 575484/90 quadrillion = 6.4 billionths of a gram change in mass. This is a small, but barely measurable difference in mass. You do indeed lose mass when cooling things.

I hope this can help. Every substance can be seen as a combination of a few atoms, and even atoms can be seen as a combination of a few particles. However, those particles are just a combination of three types of quarks, particles with a fractional charge. A proton (+1 charge) is made of two quarks with 2/3 charges (+4/3 charge) and one quark with a negative 1/3 charge equally +3/3 or +1 charge. A +2/3 charge quark and two -1/3 charge quarks make a 0 charge particle, the neutron.

In classical mechanics, the mass of an object is related to the force required to accelerate it and hence is related to its inertia , and is essential to Newton's laws of motion . Objects that have mass interact with each other through the force of gravity . In Special Relativity, the observed mass of an object is dependent on its velocity with respect to the observer, with higher velocity entailing higher observed mass.

The least a proton can have is 3 (up, up, down). Additional quarks come in quark/anti-quark pairs. So, the total number of quarks in a proton is 3+2n where n is the number of extra pairs. 2n is necessarily an even number due to it being a multiple of 2. When you add an odd number (3) to an even number (2n) you always get an odd number.
